Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2019 IEEE International Conference on Green and Sustainable Computing (IEEE IGSC)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports student travel support to the International Green and Sustainable Computing Conference (IGSC), a leading conference in this area. The conference will enable researchers and students to the study and practice of using computing resources efficiently, which in turn can impact a spectrum of economic, ecological, and social objectives. Green computing has become an established interdisciplinary research area spanning across the fields of computer science and engineering, electrical engineering, and other engineering disciplines. With these funds, 20 travel grants will be provided to students who may otherwise not be able to attend IGSC and take advantage of the available learning and networking opportunities in the newly evolving research area of green computing.

This provides the students the opportunity to:
o Interact with top researchers in their research domain;
o Learn, listen, and exchange ideas with other students working in their research domain to build future collaborations;
o Learn what is considered state-of-the-art in Green and Sustainable Computing; and
o Attend topic specific workshops held in conjunction (which are not yet finalized), but from experience, they should be excellent and meaningful.

A very solid and dedicated recruitment strategy is presented on attracting and supporting women and under-represented minority students to attend the conference.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Tenth International Green and Sustainable Computing Conference (IGSC) [https://www.igscc.org] was held in October 2019 in Alexandria, VA. IGSC is technically cosponsored by IEEE and addresses key issues and topics related to energy efficiency in computing as well as computational sustainability. The conference aims to provide a forum to a wide audience for discussing, sharing, and investigating the state-of-the-art for all aspects of green and sustainable computing, ranging from energy-efficient algorithm and software designs to power-aware circuit, architecture, and hardware designs to sustainable large-scale supercomputers, cloud services, and data centers.

The conference program included:

i) Peer-reviewed paper presentations in multiple technical sessions;

ii) A Ph.D. Forum poster-presentation session;

iii) Three keynote speeches: Iris Bahar from Brown University; Tarek El-Ghazawi from George Washington University; and John Peterson from AECOM; 

iv) Two panel sessions: Investment in Sustainability; and Heterogeneous Computing for Energy Efficiency; 

v) Fours workshops in various areas of sustainable computing: International Workshop on Big Data Analytics of Cyber-Physical (Energy) Systems; Workshop on Computing with Unconventional Technologies (CUT): From Processing to Interconnects, and Beyond; International Workshop on Quantum Computing for Sustainable Computing; and Workshop on Energy-Efficient Machine Learning. 

The NSF student travel funds were used to support 20 students, with 20% female students, from 17 different universities to attend the conference. The students participated in the Ph.D. Student Forum poster session and presented their research work in the areas of sustainable computing and computational sustainability. The students had many opportunities to interact with senior researchers in the green computing area and enjoyed networking occasions with fellow student researchers.
